Jonathan pertenece a la ventanilla ANCHOVETA se encuentre ubicada en la parroquia Puerto Pechiche recinto Anchoveta pertenece al Canton Pueblo Viejo se dedica a labores agricolas.

Jonathan se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maiz, arroz, soya, además se dedica a la crianza de cerdos. Las compras y las ventas las realiza en Ventanas.

Solicita el crédito para la compra de semillas, fertilizantres, abonos, una bomba. El credito le ayudado a suplir las necesidades de la familia y de la produccion. El sueño es sembrar cacao y comprar una casa.

Los desafíos a los que se ha enfrentado es el mal clima y la competencia. En los tiempos libres le gusta jugar futbool y cartas.
texts.en:
Jonathan is 23 years old, in a common-law marriage, and has one child. He lives with his partner and his son in the Pueblo Viejo canton of the Los Rios province. Jonathan belongs to the Anchoveta communal bank, which is located in the Puerto Pechiche parish of the Anchoveta district in the Pueblo Viejo canton. Anchoveta works with agricultural enterprises.

Jonathan works in agriculture, planting corn, rice, and soy. He also raises pigs. He buys his supplies and sells his products in Ventanas.

He requests the loan to buy seeds, fertilizers, compost, and a pump. The loan will help him provide for the needs of his family and his crops.

His dream is to plant cacao and to buy a house. The challenges that he has faced include bad weather and competition. In his free time, he likes to play soccer and cards.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizer, compost, and a pump.

loans.name: Matauaina

texts.en:
Matauaina is a 39-year-old married woman with six children. 

She has a small plantation and grows taro to earn a living. She has been doing this for many years. Matauaina has requested a loan to buy a backpack sprayer, bush-knives, fertilizer, file, and chemicals for her taro root crop and to pay for school fees. 

She has been a member of SPBD since 2009. With her profits, Matauaina hopes to improve her family standard of living and her kids' education

loans.use: to buy a backpack sprayer, bush-knives, fertilizer, file, and chemicals for her taro root crop and to pay for school fees

loans.name: Repeka

texts.en:
Repeka is a 39-year-old married woman with five children. 

She has a small plantation and grows taro to earn a living. She has been doing this for many years. Repeka has requested a loan to buy a pickaxe, bush-knives, backpack sprayer, file, axe and chain saw. 

She has been a member of SPBD since 2010. With her profits, Repeka hopes to improve her family standard of living and to invest some in her children's education.

loans.use: to buy a pickaxe, bush-knives, backpack sprayer, file, axe, and chainsaw

loans.name: Patience 2 & 3 Group

texts.fr:
Paguy est le coordinateur de son groupe Patience. Il est  marie et Il a 2 enfants. Il habite dans la region nord est d'Haïti ou de électricité est rare et de l'eau portable est très limité. Il dirige son commerce de vente de sandales pendants les 5 derniers années

Avant de ce commercer ce commerce il était  une étudiant. Paguy va utiliser votre prêt pour l'achat de chaussures, sandales et le tennis. Il espère que cet emprunt l’aidera a grandir son commerce.  Des autres membres de Patience  ont besoin d’un  emprunt pour le commerce tel que ventes produits cosmétiques boissons gazeuses etc.  Il  dit que son défit  principal est de devenir un plus grand commerçant

Paguy  dit son but principal c’est d’avoir un plus grande commerce qui lui facilitera  à  voyagé dans des autre pays.
texts.en:
Paguy is the coordinator of the Patience group. He is married, has two children, and lives in the north-east of Haiti, where electricity is scarce and drinking water is very limited. He has had a business selling sandals for the past five years.

Before starting this business, Paguy was a student. He plans to use his loan to buy shoes, sandals and sneakers, and hopes that the loan will help him to expand his business. Other members of the Patience group need loans for their businesses, which include the sale of cosmetic products and sodas. Paguy says that his main challenge is figuring out how to be a more successful retailer. He also says that his main goal is to have a larger business, which will allow him to travel to other countries.

loans.use: To buy shoes, sandals and sneakers

loans.name: Purity

texts.en:
Purity is a 25-year-old married woman. She has a child who is two years old. She describes herself to be ambitious and determined. She operates a cereals store where she sells maize and beans. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in an urban area with high potential, and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be transport. 

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to purchase beans for resale. Her business goal is to supply cereals to other towns within five years. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM. She will use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase beans for resale.

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en:
Esterlita is a 50-year-old single woman from Talibon, Bohol. She is engaged in farming and grows rice. She has been into farming for almost nine years.

She requested a loan of 7,000 PHP to buy fertilizers, pesticides and more rice seedlings, to yield more harvest. 

In the future, Esterlita would like to invest in other business ventures to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, pesticides and more rice seedlings.

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is a 35-year-old married man. He has six children with ages ranging from 3 years to 13 years. He describes himself to be honest and faithful. 

He operates a grinding mill where he grinds maize and sells maize flour. He has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located in a suburban area, and his primary customers are locals. 

He will use the 20,000 Kenyan shillings loan to buy maize and fuel for the grinding machine. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: buy maize and fuel for the grinding machine.

loans.name: Vaitapu

texts.en:
Vaitapu is 43 years old and married with 5 children. She runs a small business selling coconut biscuits in her community and has been doing this for 2 years. 

Vaitapu has requested a loan to buy a kerosene oven, frying pan, flour, dripping  oil, baking soda, sugar, eggs and foil. She joined SPBD in 2009 to gain access to capital.  Vaitapu will use her earnings to improve her business to earn more money and save it for her children's education.

loans.use: buy ingredients to make biscuits to sell

loans.name: Pupu

texts.en:
Pupu is a 59-year-old woman who is married with 5 children. She has a small sewing business.  Pupu is asking for a loan to help her pay for her  daughter's university fee and registration. She will also use part of the loan to buy materials, threads and needles for her sewing business.

Pupu joined SPBD in 2006 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: pay for her daughter's university fee and buy sewing supplies

loans.name: Kanata Colca Group

texts.es: El Banco de emprendimiento KANATA COLCA está  compuesto por nueve integrantes, seis mujeres y tres varones, ,  la presidenta del banco es la Sra. Lucy tiene 51 años casada con Cuatro  hijos, ella se dedica a la  venta de comida en su puesto de venta que se encuentra   en su mismo domicilio,  este préstamo es su primera secuencia dentro de la institución, la Sra. Lucy utilizara este préstamo para la compra de insumos para la elaboración de comida como papa, arroz y fideo al por mayor  y así de esta manera mejorar sus ventas e incrementar su capital de trabajo su razón para solicitar este préstamo es la falta de capital para la compra de insumos, la Sra. Lucy va a utilizar los beneficios para seguir comprando cantidad de insumos,  su deseo de la Sra. Lucy es crecer en su negocio, es una persona trabajadora se siente feliz y agradecida con la institución por el apoyo que le brindan en la otorgación del crédito.
texts.en:
The community bank Kanata Colca is made up of nine members, six of whom are women.  The president of the group is Lucy.  She is a 51-year-old married woman with four children.  She runs a food stall which is located at her home.  

This is her first loan from this institution.  She will use the funds in order to buy ingredients for food preparation at wholesale, such as potatoes, rice and noodles.  This will enable her to build up her inventory and improve her sales.  She is seeking this loan due to lack of working capital to buy ingredients.

Lucy wishes to grow her business.  She is a hardworking person who is grateful to this institution for making it possible to receive this loan.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for food preparation at wholesale, such as potatoes, rice and noodles.

loans.name: Saofai

texts.en:
Saofai is 57 years old and married with 8 children. She runs a small business selling fish in her community and has been doing this for many years. 

Saofai has requested a loan to buy a cooler, snorkels, goggles, spears and nets for her fishing business. She joined SPBD in 2010 to gain access to capital. With her earnings, Saofai will improve her business to save more money for her children's future.

loans.use: buy a cooler, snorkels, goggles, spears and nets to fish

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch is 60 years old and married.  She lives in a thatched roof house in a rural village in the Sa Ang district of Kandal province.  She and her husband have two children.  They earn a living through farming and fishing and they have been in this business for forty years. With her current business, Touch is able to earn approximately 27,000 KHR per day to support her family.   

This is the first loan for Touch with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund.   She is requesting for a loan of 1,500,000 KHR to buy fertilizers for her farm. She hopes to grow her business so as to make a better living.

loans.use: buy fertilizers for her farm

loans.name: Lany

texts.en:
Lany, 62, is married with two dependent children, both of whom are dependent on her and still in school. Her family lives in a house with a thatched roof located in Battambang province’s Thmor Koul district. 

The main sources of her family’s income are from farming rice, and growing cabbage and salad. The current business earns her about 32,000 KHR per day to meet the family’s needs. 

Lany has been with VisionFund for six cycles. She completely paid back the past loans. Now she is applying for another loan of 2,000,000 KHR to buy fertilizers, pesticides and seeds for her farmland. She hopes this loan will help her to get a high yield from her plantation.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, pesticides and seeds for her farmland.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a 43-year old married woman. She has 2 children with ages 10 years and 15 years. She describes herself to be optimistic. 

Beatrice operates a grocery store where she sells tomatoes, onions, potatoes, etc. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in an area with potential and her primary customers are individuals.  She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of enough capital. 

Beatrice will use this KES 20,000 loan to add stock of tomatoes, onions, potatoes and other items. Her business goal is to have a bigger business within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will have several branches of grocery store. 

This is Beatrice's second loan with SMEP DTM.  Her previous loan of KES 20,000 was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to educate her children.

loans.use: buy vegetables to sell

loans.name: Emeliana

texts.en:
Emeliana is a 50-year-old married woman from Getafe, Bohol. She is engaged in a gravel business. She buys and sells sand and gravel to customers in the community. 

To continue pursue her day-to-day living, Emeliana requested a loan of 4,000 PHP to buy more sand and gravel to avoid a shortage of supply.  In the future, Emeliana hopes that she can buy her own truck, which will be very helpful in her sand and gravel business, especially for transporting it from one place to another.

loans.use: buy sand and gravel

loans.name: Argie

texts.en:
Argie is a 29-year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol.  She is the mother of a 2-year-old daughter. 

Argie runs a retail store where she sells various items like cooking oil, noodles, canned goods, shampoos and soaps. She has been operating this retail store for almost 5 years.

Argie requested a loan of 8,000 PHP to buy various items like soft drinks and dry goods to attract more customers.  In the future, she would like expand her retail store business to provide her child with good living conditions.

loans.use: restock her store

loans.name: Saem's Group

texts.en:
Saem, 42, is the mother of five children and a resident of a rural village of the Moung Russey district. The main source of her family’s income is farming rice, which she has done for several years. Saem is able to earn about KHR 12,000 per day to meet the family’s needs.
This is the fifth loan for Saem with VisionFund. She completely paid back the past loans. Now, she is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, Saem will use her portion to buy fertilizer and pesticides for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase crop yield so as to make a better living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides for her farmland

loans.name: Fidencia Del Pilar

texts.es:
En el cantón Rocafuerte se reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal Rocafuerte. Este lugar se lo conoce por sus deliciosos dulces que preparan los lugareños y que son reconocidos en todo el país.

En este lugar vive la señora Fidencia, tiene 53 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos mayores de edad, uno de ellos  aun vive con ella a pesar de estar comprometido. Su esposo es comerciante.

Doña Fidencia  es una gran ama de casa que tiene un negocio de venta de queso y leche de soya en su casa, lugar al que acuden sus clientes día a día ya que son deliciosos los productos que vende. Tres veces por semana compra el queso al por mayor que le envían desde Chone para luego venderlo por libras en su pequeño local, trabaja todos los días desde las 7h00 hasta las 17h00, trabaja sola ya que el trabajo no es tan difícil, viene realizando esta actividad por 17 años con lo cual ayudo a su sus hijos a salir adelante.

Este crédito es para comprar quesos y leche de soya. Lleva más de 5 años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la facilidad para conseguir los créditos y por la ayuda que le dan para seguir adelante. 

Su sueño es tener un carro.
texts.en:
The members of the Rocafuerte Community Bank meet every fifteen days in the canton of Rocafuerte.  This area is known for the delicious sweets made by the locals.  These products are recognized throughout all of Ecuador.

Fidencia lives in this area.  She is a 53-year-old married woman with three children.  One of them still lives with her even though he is engaged.  Her husband is a vendor.

She is a great homemaker and also has a business selling soy milk and cheese from her home.  Her customers come to her day after day to buy her delicious products.  Three times per week she buys her cheese at wholesale.  It is sent to her from Chone.  She then sells it by the pound from her home.  She works every day from 7 am to 5 pm.  She works on her own since the work is not too difficult.  She has been doing this work for 17 years and has thus been able to provide her children with a better life.

This loan will be used to buy soy milk and cheese. Fidencia has been a member of this communal bank for five years.  She appreciates the ease with which she can obtain loans, and she is grateful for the support they provide to assist her in meeting her goals.

Her dream is to have a car.

loans.use: to purchase soy milk and cheese for resale.

loans.name: Nap's Group

texts.en:
Nap, 56, is a widowed mother of three children who lives in a rural village of the Moung Russey district, Cambodia. To support her family, she has been growing rice for 28 years. She can earn about 12,000 KHR per day meet the family’s needs. 
Nap has been with VisionFund for four loans. She completely paid back the past loans, which have helped her relieve her family’s burden. Now she is leading her group of two to apply for a loan. As the leader, she wants to use her portion to buy fertilizer and seed for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her family’s income to make a better living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seed for her farmland

loans.name: Sothor's Group

texts.en:
Sothor, 63, is married with one dependent child. He lives in a rural area of Battambang province's Moung Russey district, Cambodia. Growing pineapple has been his main source of income for 18 years. The current business earns him approximately KHR 23,000 per day to meet his family's needs. 
This is the third micro loan for Sothor with VisionFund. He successfully paid back the loans which have helped him better support his family. Now, he is leading his group to ask for a loan. As the leader, Sothor will use his portion to buy fertilizer for his farmland. He hopes to grow his pineapple on time so as to make a better living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for his farmland

loans.name: Sophorn's Group

texts.en:
Sophorn, 48, is married and lives with her husband and four children in a village of the Moungkul Borey district of Banteay Meanchey province. She and her husband are farmers who grow rice in their village. Sophorn supplements their income by selling vegetables. She and her husband have been in business for 25 years, earning about 25,000 KHR per day to feed their family. 
Sophorn has been with VisionFund for five loans. She is now leading her group to request a loan to buy fertilizer for her farmland and use a portion of it to buy vegetables to resell. She hopes to increase her crop yields and earn more income to improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farmland

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkul Borey District

loans.name: Nor

texts.en:
Nor is 57 years old, married and the mother of seven children. To make a living, she and her husband have been electric welding for 37 years. The current business earns them about 57,000 KHR per day to meet the family needs.
Nor has no previous loans with VisionFund. She is applying for a loan of 4,000,000 KHR to buy materials for supporting her business. She hopes this loan will enable her to earn more income for her family so as to make a better living.

loans.use: To buy materials for supporting her business.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ou Reang Ov district

loans.name: Pov's Group

texts.en:
Pov, 37, is married and lives with her husband and two children in a village of the Ponhea Krek district of Kampong Cham province. She and her husband are rice farmers who grow rice and cassava in the village. She and her husband have been in the rice farming business for 17 years, earning about 28,000 KHR per day to feed the family. 

Pov has been with VisionFund for three cycles and completely paid back the past loans, which have helped her better support her family. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland and use a portion of it to pay for laborers. She hopes to increase her crop yields and earn more income to better her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Mom's Group

texts.en:
Aged 41 years, Mom is a rural villager from the Ponheak Krek district. She earns a living through planting cassava and rice. It is the main source of her family’s income and she has been in this business for twenty-one years. To earn additional income, her husband works for others for a fee. 

Mom has been with VisionFund for one cycle. She fully repaid her previous loan. Now she is leading her group of four members to ask for a new loan. Mom, who is the leader, will use her portion to buy fertilizer for her plantation. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her crop yields and sell it for a good price so she can make a better living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her plantation

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Senghean's Group

texts.en:
Senghean, 48, is married with six dependent children. She lives in a rural area of Kampong Cham province's Prey Chhor district, in Cambodia. Rice farming has been her main source of income for 30 years. To supplement her income, she also works as a garment worker. The current business earns her approximately KHR 10,000 per day to help meet her family's needs. 

Senghean has been with VisionFund for one cycle. Now she is leading her group of four to ask for a new loan. As the leader, Senghean is going to use her portion to buy fertilizer and seeds for her farmland. She hopes to get a high yield from her paddy-field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: Chen's Group

texts.en:
Originally from a rural village of the Ponhea Leur district of Kampong Cham province, Chen is a 34-year-old mother of four children. Rice farming has been the only source of income for her family for 3 years. The current business earns her about 20,000 KHR per day and she can manage to save about 5,000 KHR each day after daily expenses. 

Chen has just joined VisionFund this cycle. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. She is going to use her portion to buy materials for building a decent latrine. She hopes to have a clean latrine for her family to use.

loans.use: To buy materials for building a decent latrine

loans.name: Ruth María

texts.es:
En el cantón Rocafuerte se reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal Rocafuerte. Este lugar se lo conoce por sus deliciosos dulces que preparan los lugareños y que son reconocidos en todo el país.

En este lugar vive la señora Ruth, tiene 67 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen cuatro hijos todos mayores de edad, ella y su esposo viven en casa de una de sus hijos. Su esposo ya no trabaja por razones de la edad, el era agricultor.

Doña Ruth para ganar algo por su cuenta se dedica a la venta  de ropa y productos de  Avon y Yanbal (artículos de belleza, cosméticos perfumería y accesorios para damas). Trabaja todos los días dos horas por las mañanas, su forma de venta es puerta a puerta y por pedidos, ella  deja a crédito y cobra en dos o tres partes dependiendo  del valor del producto, Lo que más vende son los cosméticos y los perfumes, lleva más de 8 años en este negocio y le va bien, con esto ella tiene para sus gastos de medicinas y los de su marido. 

Este crédito es para comprar ropa, perfumes, bisutería, cosméticos y cremas. Está en el Banco Comunal desde hace 14 años, es la tesorera del banco y le gusta porque los créditos le han ayudado mucho. 

Su sueño es tener buena salud.
texts.en:
The members of the Rocafuerte Community Bank meet every fifteen days in the canton of Rocafuerte.  This area is known for the delicious sweets made by the local residents.  These products are recognized throughout all of Ecuador.

Ruth lives in this area.  She is a 67-year-old married woman with four adult children.  She and her husband live in one of their children's homes.  Her husband was a farmer but is now retired.

In order to earn money, Ruth sells clothing as well as Avon and Yanbal products such as cosmetics and women's accessories.   She works every morning, selling her products door-to-door and taking orders.  She extends credit to her customers and collects the balances due in two or three installments, depending on the value of the item.  Her best-selling items are cosmetics and perfumes. She has been in this business for over eight years, and things are going well.  She is able to earn enough money for her medical expenses and those of her husband.  

She is seeking this loan in order to purchase clothing, perfumes, jewelry and creams.  She has been a member of this communal bank for fourteen years.  She is the treasurer of the bank, and she likes it very much because the loans have helped her a great deal.

Her dream is to have good health.

loans.use: to purchase clothing, perfumes, jewelry and creams.

loans.name: Eat's Group

texts.en:
A married father of six children, Eat is 46 years old and lives in a rural village of the Sampov Meas district, in Cambodia. To support his family, he and his wife have been farming rice and growing corn for 20 years. They can earn about 42,000 KHR per day to help meet the family’s needs.

Eat has been with VisionFund for one cycle. He completely paid back the previous loan, which has helped him relieve the burden on his family. Now he is leading his group of four to apply for a new loan. As the leader, he wants to use his portion to buy fertilizers and seeds for his farmland. He hopes this loan will enable him to increase his family’s income and make a better living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds for his farmland

loans.name: Chuneng

texts.en:
A citizen from a rural area of the Srey Santhor district of Kampong Cham province, Chuneng is 22-year-old married woman. To make a living, she has been working as a nurse in a village. To supplement her income she also grows rice. The current business earns her about US $3 per day to help meet her family’s needs. 

Chuneng has just joined Kiva partner VisionFund this cycle. Now she is applying for a loan to pay the entire fee for her husband’s education; he is specializing in education at a university in the area. She hopes this loan will support her husband until his graduation so he can get a good job and help her improve their standard of living.

loans.use: to pay the entire fee for her husband’s education

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is married and has five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past six years, she has owned a food stall business for neighbours and town dwellers. She faces a major challenge of fluctuations in the prices of the goods.

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour and salt for resale. She dreams of expanding to a modern shop for the business.

loans.use: to purchase goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour and salt for resale.

loans.name: Kadide

texts.en:
Kadide is a married woman and has been blessed with three children who attend school. She lives in her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

Kadide has operated a poultry-selling business, which has been operational for over four years. She mentioned disease outbreaks that cause losses as a challenge in the business and she dreams of becoming a wholesaler of poultry in the future. 

With the KES 20,000 loan, Kadide wants to purchase chicks and poultry feed. She joined Yehu Microfinance Trust to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and poultry feed.

loans.name: Renato Carlos

texts.es:
En el cantón Rocafuerte se reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal Rocafuerte. Este lugar se lo conoce por sus deliciosos dulces que preparan los lugareños y que son reconocidos en todo el país.

En este lugar vive el señor Renato, tiene 25 años, es soltero y vive en la casa de una  tía, estudia el último semestre de ingeniería  civil en una Universidad Técnica De Manabí, de la cual espera graduarse y así poder ejercer su profesión para su bien y el de su familia.

Él además de preocuparse por sus estudios también se dedica al comercio, vende sabanas, cobertores de colchones, sobrecamas  y fundas de almohadas, mismas  que su tía elabora y que él se encarga de comercializar, su forma de venta es puerta a puerta y la mayor parte de sus ventas son  por pedidos que sus clientes le realizan con anticipación, trabaja todos los días en las mañanas ya que en las tardes y noches tiene que dedicarse a sus estudios, gracias a este negocio ha podido seguir adelante en sus estudios.

Este crédito es para comprar telas e hilos para elaborar las  sabanas y cobertores. Lleva 4 años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque los intereses son bajos. 

Su sueño es terminar sus estudios y ejercer su profesión.
texts.en:
Every other week in the canton of Rocefuerte, the members of the Rocafuerte Community Bank meet. This area is known for the delicious desserts the locals make and are popular throughout the entire country.

This is where Renato lives. He is single, 25 years old, and lives in his aunt's home. He is in his final semester of civil engineering at the Technical University of Manabí. He hopes to graduate and be able to work in this profession for the benefit of himself and his family. 

In addition to this studies, Renato also manages a business selling the linens, mattress covers, bedspreads, and pillowcases that his aunt makes. He makes his sales door to door and the majority of his sales come through orders made in advance. He works everyday in the morning because  he then concentrates on his studies in the afternoons and evenings. Thanks to this business he's been able to keep up with his studies. 

This loan will be used to purchase thread and fabric for making sheets and blankets. Renato has been a member of this community bank for four years, and he likes it because the interest rates are low. His goal is to finish his studies and find work in his field.

loans.use: purchase thread and fabric.

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas is a married mother who has kids and lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.  For the past two years, she has operated a brick selling business. She operates from home, where neighbours and passersby are her potential customers. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her business to accommodate more customers in the future. With her KES 20,000 loan she wants to purchase more bricks for sale to meet the needs of her customers. She decided to join to Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase more bricks for sale to meet the needs of her customers

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is married and has children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. For the past two years, Mary has owned a food stall business, where neighbours and town dwellers are her potential customers. She faces a major challenge of fluctuations in her number of clients, and with her perishable goods this leads to losses. With her KES 20,000 loan she wants to purchase more stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour, and cooking fat. She dreams of expanding her business to a modern café.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour, and cooking fat

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary has operated a beauty salon business and her potential customers are mostly women. In addition, she operates a retail shop business which earns her another source of livelihood. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of business. 

With the loan Rosemary is requesting, she wants to purchase a stock of hair drier machines for her beauty salon business. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of hair drier machines for her beauty salon business.

loans.name: Salama

texts.en: Salama is married and has children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. For the past three years, Salama has owned a food stall business, where neighbours and town dwellers are her potential customers. She also has a business selling cereals. She faces a major challenge of fluctuations in her number of clients, and with her perishable goods this leads to losses. With her KES 30,000 loan she wants to purchase more stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour, cooking fat, and cereals for sale. She dreams of expanding her business to a modern café.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour, cooking fat, and cereals for sale.

loans.name: Amana

texts.en:
Amana is a single mother of three children, all of whom attend school. They are the reason for her hard work. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

Amana has operated a retail shop business for the past two years, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. 

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is married and has children who are all grown. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past two years, she has owned a food stall business where neighbors and town dwellers shop. With the loan of KES 50,000 she wants to purchase stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize, wheat flour and cooking oil for sale. She dreams of expanding to become a wholesale shop in the business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize, wheat flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Fransiscah

texts.en:
Fransiscah is married and has school-going children. They live in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for the family.

Fransiscah has operated a clothing sales business for the past two years. She sells from a shop to her neighbors, town dwellers, and passersby. She faces a major challenge of inflation in her business. 

With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth operates a fruit and vegetable sales business. She sells to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge in the business is seasonality.

With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase sacks of fruit, tomatoes and vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her standard of living. She appreciates the support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fruit, tomatoes and vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is married and has three children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, she has operated a business selling fruits and vegetables. She sells to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge in the business is seasonality.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of fruits and vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fruits and vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
Rachael is a married woman and has children who attend school. Her husband is a businessman and, together, they own a house that has neither electricity, nor piped water. 

Rachael has operated a tailoring business for the past three years. Her potential clients are ladies and gents. She dreams of establishing a boutique in the future. 

With the KES 50,000 loan, Rachael wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business.

loans.name: Beatríz

texts.es:
Beatriz de 56 años de edad. Es una persona que desde pequeñita se ha crecido en una familia muy humilde en el caserío, fueron sus padres quienes le enseñaron a temprana edad a elaborar hamacas, en esos entonces eran de mezcal, luego con el tiempo ella aprendió a elaborar hamacas de seda, hoy en día ella hace de poliseda y de cascarilla. Ella es madre de 5 hijos (tres varones y dos hembras) producto de su matrimonio, ellos ademas le ayudan en los cultivos de maíz y de frijoles, pues son los cultivos que ella junto con su esposo hacen para el sustento de la familia. Desde hace 10 años, también se dedica a la crianza de cerdos y aves de corral.

 Compra materiales para elaborar las hamacas en el municipio donde ella reside, le queda a 10  minutos caminando, hasta llegar al pueblo, los fertilizantes los compra también el pueblo.

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo,  es para comprar dos cerdos valorados en $100 cada uno,  el resto del dinero lo invertirá en la agricultura, pues esta preparándose para la milpa del mes de agosto. Con el crédito podrá contar con dos cerdos que permitirán en el futuro un ingreso económico para la familia, y también en cuanto al cultivo pues podrá obtener mejores cosechas. Asegurando la alimentación de la familia y a la vez dispondrá de activos para  comercializar en el futuro.

Ella sueña con comprar un terreno en la comunidad donde vive; ya que no posee una casa propia, sino que vive alquilando. Ademas su esfuerzo diario es para ayudar a sus hijos a salir adelante en los estudios de la educación media.
texts.en:
Beatriz is 56 years of age. As a small child, she grew up in a humble family in the village. Her parents taught her how to make hammocks at an early age. Back then, they were made of mezcal, then over time she learned to make silk hammocks, and today she makes them with polysilk and husks. She is the mother of five children (three males and two females) from her marriage. They also help in the cultivation of corn and beans, the crops that she and her husband grow to sustain the family. She has also been raising pigs and poultry for the last 10 years.

She buys fertilizers and materials to make hammocks in town, which is about a 10-minute walk from the village.

The loan she is requesting from Fundación Campo is to buy two pigs valued at $100 each, with the remaining money to be invested in agriculture, to prepare the cornfields for cultivation in August. With this loan, she will be able to get two pigs that will, in the future, provide income for the family; in terms of agriculture, it will mean a better harvest. At the same time, she will be able to feed her family and have assets to trade in the future.

Beatriz dreams of buying land in the community where she lives since she does not own her home, but rather rents it. In addition, their daily effort is to help their children succeed in their studies in secondary education.

loans.use: to buy two pigs valued at $ 100 each; the remaining money will be invested in agriculture, to prepare the cornfields for cultivation in August.

loans.name: Inés María

texts.es:
En el cantón Rocafuerte se reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal Rocafuerte. Este lugar se lo conoce por sus deliciosos dulces que preparan los lugareños y que son reconocidos en todo el país.

En este lugar vive la señora Inés, tiene 55 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos mayores de edad, uno de ellos que es soltero  aun vive con ella. Su esposo no trabaja por razones de salud.

Doña Inés para sacar adelante a su familia ya que su marido no puede trabajar se dedica a la venta de bocadillos y bebidas en el bar de una escuela en Rocafuerte, ella vende jugos naturales, frutas y bocadillos sanos para que los niños tengan un buen crecimiento. También prepara comida para los maestros y ciertos alumnos que almuerzan en el plantel, en la actualidad está vendiendo almuerzos pero solo para entregar, esto lo hace ya que en estos días no hay clases y la escuela está cerrada por eso ella busca la forma de ganar algo hasta que empiecen las clases y todo vuelva a la normalidad. Lleva 6 años que se dedica a esta actividad  que empezó con su primer crédito.

Este crédito es para comprar víveres para elaborar los alimentos y frutas. Lleva 6 años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque gracias al primer crédito empezó su negocio. 

Su sueño es tener un restaurante  en el centro de la ciudad.
texts.en:
Every other week in the canton of Rocefuerte, the members of the Rocafuerte Community Bank meet. This area is known for the delicious desserts the locals make and are popular throughout the entire country.

This is where Inés lives. She is 55 years old, married, and has three older children, one who is a single and lives at home with her. Her husband does not work due to health problems. 

In order to provide for her family now that her husband can no longer work, Inés works selling snacks and beverages in a school in Rocafuerte. She sells natural juices, fruits, and healthy snacks so that the children grow up healthy. She also prepares meals for the teachers and certain students who eat lunch on campus. Currently she is only selling lunches, but only for delivery as these days there are no classes and the school is closed. For this reason she is looking for a way to make money until classes start back up and everything goes back to normal. She has been running this business for six years, which she started with her first loan. 

This loan will be used to purchase fruits and other foodstuffs for preparing her lunches. Inés has been a member of the Rocafuerte Community Bank for six years, and she likes it because she was able to start her business with her first loan. Her goal is to have a restaurant located in the heart of downtown.

loans.use: purchase fruits and other foodstuffs.

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is a married mother of four children, all of whom attend school. They are the reason for her hard work. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past two years, selling household products like wheat flour, maize flour (corn flour), and sugar.

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase a stock of sugar, rice, maize flour, and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans in order to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour, and wheat flour.

loans.name: Mealii

texts.en:
Mealii is married and has three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past three years, she has owned a food stall business for neighbors and town dwellers. Her major challenge is fluctuations in her client numbers hence perishable goods going bad, leading to losses.

With the 20,000 KES, she wants to purchase a stock of goods such as sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour, and cooking fat. In business, she dreams of expanding to a modern café.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of goods such as sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour, and cooking fat.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a married woman who has been blessed with four children all of whom attend school. Together with her husband, they live at their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

She has operated a fish selling business for over three years, selling from home to restaurant operators and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality and perishability leading to losses.

With the Kshs 30,000 loan she wants to purchase bundles of fish to resell. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing another business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of fish to resell.

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia operates a food vending business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business and she dreams of expanding to a restaurant in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 loan she wants to purchase cooking fat oil, wheat flour, maize flour, and rice. She decided to join Kiva partner Yehu in order to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cooking fat oil, wheat flour, maize flour, and rice.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a married woman with kids. She lives at a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past two years, she has operated a kiosk (small shop) business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She also runs a vegetable stall to supplement her income. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business and she dreams of establishing a wholesale business in the future. With the loan that she is requesting of KES 50,000, she wants to purchase more stock of wheat flour, maize flour, and beans. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of wheat flour, maize flour, and beans.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a married woman and has kids who attend school. Her husband is a policeman and together they own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. She has operated a tailoring business for the past 3 years. Her potential clients are ladies and men. She dreams of establishing a boutique in the future. With her KES 30,000 loan she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials, sewing thread for her business

loans.name: Mwanandugu

texts.en:
Mwanandugu is married and has seven children. She owns a house that does not have electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses is food for the family. 

She has operated a food vending business for the past ten years, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business and she dreams of expanding to a restaurant in the future.

With the 5,000 KES she wants to purchase cooking oil and wheat flour for food preparation. She decided to join Yehu to access loans in order to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cooking oil and wheat flour for food preparation

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en:
Vicky is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 18,000 through Kiva partner NWTF in order to buy ingredients for her food business.

Vicky successfully paid back her previous loan and now she is getting a new loan in order to build her business.

NWTF is re-listing Vicky's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 50,000 through Kiva partner NWTF in order to purchase additional stock to sell such as bath soap, canned goods, soft-drinks, cooking oil, rice, etc. for her general store.

Gloria has been in this business for 31 years. Gloria earns more income from food vending.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her general store business.

Gloria has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell such as bath soap, canned goods, soft-drinks, cooking oil, rice, etc. for her general store

loans.name: Norie

texts.en:
Norie is married and she works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through Kiva partner NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Norie has been in this business for four years and has previously received funds through Kiva.

Norie aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is married, and has six children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a fruit and vegetable selling business. She sells to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge in the business is seasonality.

With the 30,000 KES, she wants to purchase sacks of fruits and vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans in order to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fruits and vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Meralyn

texts.en:
Meralyn is 26 years old and has two children. She is married and has two children who are in school.

Meralyn is in the agricultural business, raising livestock in the Philippines. Meralyn requested a PHP 13,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy vitamins, vaccines, and other supplies for her livestock.

Meralyn has been raising livestock for seven years now, and has borrowed eight times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

Meralyn would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy vitamins, vaccines, and other supplies for her livestock.

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is married and has three children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a fruit and vegetable selling business. She sells to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge in the business is seasonality.

With the 15,000 KES she wants to purchase sacks of fruits and vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans in order to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fruits and vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is a married mother of six children, all of whom attend school and are the reason for her hard work. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past twenty years, selling household consumables such as wheat flour, maize flour and sugar.

With the loan she is requesting she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Kiva partner Yehu in order to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour.

loans.name: Nusura

texts.en:
Nusura is a married woman who has been blessed with three children all of whom attend school. Together with her husband, they live at their own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. 

She has operated a fish selling business for over three years, selling from home to restaurant operators and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality and perishability leading to losses.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase bundles of fish to resell. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing another business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of fish to resell.

loans.name: Abida's Group

texts.en:
Abida is a 38 year-old married woman. She is the mother of five children. She adores her family and her husband works very hard so that his family can have a good and respectable life. Eight years ago, her husband started his own business selling welding material. 

Abida, as a member of a two person lending group, is requesting a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan for her husband. He will use the loan amount to increase his supply of welding products including iron rods, iron sheets, soldering rods, welding rods, etc. so that he can respond quickly to customer needs. He plans to expand his business with the additional income he earns. Abida hopes that the loan will be helpful for her husband's business. She is thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to purchase iron rods and sheets, soldering rods, welding rods, etc.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe DANAYA ont en moyenne 30 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à LAFIABOUGOU  un des quartiers de la ville de SAN de la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente de produits alimentaires tels les condiments alimentaires,  et la restauration et de produits divers.
les femmes du groupe DANAYA sont à leur 1 er  prêt solidaire. KOUMBA 1 ère femme de la gauche  vers la droite sur la photo compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des cartons de sachets de lait en poudre.
 Elles s’approvisionnent à SAN et les foires environnantes. Elles effectuent ses ventes, sur place à SAN, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de17 500FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group DANAYA average 30 years of age and four children each, all living in traditional extended families in LAFIABOUGOU, a district in San City (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know one another through ties of kinship. They buy and sell grocery items, such as condiments, and general goods, and they work in food service. The women of the group DANAYA are on their first solidarity loan. 

KOUMBA, who is the first woman from the left in the photo, intends to use her loan to purchase boxes of powdered milk in pouches.

The women get their supplies in San and the surrounding fairs. They make their sales locally to men and women customer in San.

They envision making an average monthly profit of 17,500 francs CFA that will be used for expenses associated with healthcare, food, and school fees. The rest will be reinvested in their businesses.

loans.use: to purchase milk powder

loans.name: Marie Anne

texts.en:
Ras Al Nabeh is a  group of three Filipino women who work as housekeepers for Lebanese families in order to make their living and send money to their beloved ones in their Philippine homeland.

They joined hands to acquire a loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua because it is the best way for them to achieve their needs.

Velliamor is the featured borrower of the Ras Al Nabeh Group and she is a 37-year-old single mother of three children. She works hard to provide them with the best living ever. Her children live with her family back in the Philippines so she has to put extra effort to provide them with almost everything they need to make up for them because she is far away at the time when they need her most.

Velliamor is the first one standing at the left and her applied for loan will be invested in paying for her children's school tuition fees.

As for the other group members, Marie Anne is the one standing in the middle with a yellow shirt, and Rea is the first from the right.

loans.use: to send money for her children's school tuition fees.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en:
Sandra is married and she works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from a grocery store. Sandra is borrowing 13,000 PHP through NWTF to buy fishing gear and other equipment for her fishing business.

Sandra has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

loans.name: Girlie

texts.en:
As a married mother of three children, Girlie works hard to support her family.
 
She has a general store business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from an Avon dealership.  Girlie is borrowing 12,000 PHP through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Girlie has been sustaining her business activities through her past six loans from NWTF and, more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dreams: to save money in order to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam operates a retail shop business, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour and sugar.

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She appreciates the support given.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy general merchandise such as cooking oil, water, soda and cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Djiguisseme 5 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe  Benkadi 6 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans, 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles traditionnelles à KAMPOGOSSO, un des villages de la commune de  Kimparana cercle de SAN, 4ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur 5 eme  prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est  l’arachide  avec  FATOUMATA  DRISSA,  1 er débout  de la gauche vers la droite avec un foullard couleur vert vif  sur la photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, des semences, des petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir 1,5 hectare. 
La production sera vendue au niveau du village et à San, après la récolte, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 170 500FCFA en fin de campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group "Benkadi 6" are married women, who average 41 years of age and four children each, all living in traditional families in KAMPOGOSSO, a village in Commune de  Kimparana, in Cercle de SAN (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their farm work during the rainy season. They are on their fifth loan with the institution. The past loans were indeed paid back. 

The crop grown is peanuts, as is the case with FATOUMATA DRISSA, who is the first one standing from the left and wearing a bright green scarf in the photo. With her loan, she intends to purchase some farm inputs, seeds, and sundry equipment and to pay the cost of plowing to maintain 1.5 hectares.

After the harvest, the produce will be sold to men and women customers in the village and in San. She plans on making a profit of 170,500 francs CFA at the end of planting. This profit will enable her to repay her loan and also to help her husband to cover day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, farm inputs, seeds, and sundry equipment.

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
This is Rowena, 34, a resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Genelito, a worker abroad, and is a mother to her children. Since her husband is abroad, she is the one managing their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to provide income for their family.

Rowena operates an Internet café business. Services like this become a need as customers’ demand increases. Her main patrons are students, who require her services for school requirements. She has customers who need to rent computers for business purposes like writing a resume or any office documentation, as well as customers who would just love to surf the 'net and visit any social network. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP (Philippines pesos) in profit every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional computer parts and accessories needed in her business.

Rowena hopes that her business will get bigger and dreams that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional computer parts and supplies needed in her business.

loans.name: Nikanou Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe NIKANOU ont en moyenne 38 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à LAFIABOUGOU  un des quartiers de la ville de SAN (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente de produits alimentaires tels les condiments alimentaires,  et la restauration et de produits divers.
les femmes du groupe NIKANOU sont à leur 14 eme  prêt solidaire. FANTA 1 ère femme debout de la gauche  vers la droite sur la photo  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  1 bidon de vingt litres d’huile alimentaire, un sac d’oignon et quelques cartons de cube Maggi.
 Elles s’approvisionnent à SAN et les villages environnants. Elles effectuent ses ventes, sur place à SAN, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 80 500FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group NIKANOU average 38 years of age and four children each, all living in traditional extended families in LAFIABOUGOU, a district in San City (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know one another through ties of kinship. They buy and sell grocery items, such as condiments, and general goods, and they work in food service. The women of the group NIKANOU are on their 14th solidarity loan. 

FANTA, who is the first woman from the left in the photo, intends to use her loan to purchase a 20-liter container of cooking oil, a sack of onions, and a few boxes of Maggi bouillon cubes.

The women get their supplies in San and the surrounding villages. They make their sales locally to men and women customer in San.

They envision making an average monthly profit of 80,500 francs CFA that will be used for expenses associated with healthcare, food, and school fees. The rest will be reinvested in their businesses.

loans.use: to purchase food supplies

loans.name: Prak

texts.en:
Prak is a 41-year-old married woman and an industrious mother of four children. Two of her children are employed and the other two children are still students. Prak described herself as a humble farmer who is patient in her current business. In the farming business, Prak operates on small pieces of farmland. She gains less income than her husband does in a fish vending business, which could earn around $10.00 per day.

Prak is requesting a loan amounting to 500 US dollars to build a bathroom to serve her family members. This construction will enable the family to gain access to a clean bathroom with better sanitation. This is her eighth loan cycle with HKL; she mentioned her previous loans were great support in improving her living standards.

loans.use: to build a bathroom to serve her family members.

loans.name: Jinky

texts.en:
Jinky is 35 years old and married with two children.

Jinky works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Jinky has been in this business for 12 years and has previously received funds through Kiva.

Jinky aspires to save money in order to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 25,000 PHP through NWTF to buy a fishing net and other equipment.

Erlinda successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her fishing business.

NWTF is re-listing Erlinda's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy a fishing net and other equipment.

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en:
Eugenia is 50 years old and married with four children.

Eugenia is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. Eugenia requested a 30,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF in order to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Eugenia has been raising pigs for 17 years now, and has borrowed 23 times in the past from NWTF, and more recently from Kiva, to sustain it.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza is married, and she works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending. Analiza is borrowing 25,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation in order to purchase more groceries to sell to her customers.

Analiza has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Rizel

texts.en:
This is Rizel, 29, a resident of Intramuros, Philippines. She is married to William and is a mother to her children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to provide income for their family.

Rizel operates an Internet café business. Services like this become a need as customers’ demand increases. Her main patrons are students, who require her services for school requirements. She has customers who need to rent computers for business purposes like writing a resume or any office documentation, as well as customers who would just love to surf the 'net and visit any social network. She also has a food stall and she sells fruits. She earns a minimum of 2,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) in profit every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 22,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional computer parts and accessories needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Rizel hopes that her business will get bigger and dreams to have a better living. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she finds strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional computer parts and supplies needed in her business.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
This is Corazon, 48, a resident of Intramuros, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Nilo, a carpenter, and is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband and children, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Corazon operates a food processing business. She has a factory a few steps from her house where they manufacture meat products. She earns by selling her goods to the market. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional processed and frozen meat products to expand her product inventory.

Corazon hopes that her business gets bigger and dreams of having a good future. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for more frozen and processed foods needed in her business.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 56 years old, married and has eight children. 

Erlinda is in the agricultural business, raising livestock in the Philippines. Erlinda requested a 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her livestock.

Erlinda has been raising livestock for two years now, and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Erlinda would like to save money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her livestock.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn is a married woman with one child. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She is 51 years old and her child is in school.

Merlyn has a business buying and selling livestock in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional livestock to sell.

Merlyn has been in this business for 12 years. She would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional livestock to sell

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is 39 years old and married with six children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Ruth is borrowing 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF in order to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Ruth has been raising pigs for two years and also earns additional income from charcoal retailing.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: I Wayan

texts.en:
I Wayan,lives with his wife who works as a kindergarten teacher. He has two daughters in college. He has a grass-cutting business. Because his work satisfies his customers, he has a lot of customers. Now, he feels overwhelmed to serve all these customers. 

For that reason, he needs a loan to buy a mower and the spare parts for it. He will hire an employee to help him. The price for one mower is around 3,000,000 IDR. He hopes that, with his new employee, his service will be more satisfying, all work can be completed on time and his income will increase. His  staff person will be paid in accordance with the land he works on. All profits will be saved for retirement purposes.

loans.use: To buy one mower and the spare parts for it

loans.name: Harini

texts.en:
To support the productivity of her business, Harini needs a motorcycle to carry fish from the fisherman to her store. She needs fast delivery so that she can sell the fish quickly to her customers. She needs a loan of 5,000,000 IDR to purchase a motorcycle.

Harini hopes, the faster she can provide fish, the more customers she can serve, and then she will have more earnings. All the profit will be saved for her family needs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Arnel

texts.en:
This is Arnel. He previously accessed a 12,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan that he used to buy spare parts and accessories for the maintenance of his tricycle unit. His earnings were a big help in the education of his children and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

Arnel would like to apply for a 14,000 PHP loan to buy spare parts for the maintenance of their tricycle unit and also to buy some equipment for their repair shop. His profits from the business will definitely help him to cover their daily needs and the educational expenses of his children. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Arnel dreams of expanding his business and having more sources of income. He hopes to give his children a good life and education. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week. This is where he also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for the spare parts and maintenance of his tricycle unit.

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
This is Nida. She previously accessed a 25,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase merchandise items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big for her children’s education and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 25,000 PHP loan to buy more merchandise items and products to increase her product inventory. The more items she has on display and available on hand, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her children’s education and cover their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Nida hopes to grow her business and have her own store for her business. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies and merchandise  like clothing, footwear, undergarments, and cosmetics needed in her business.

loans.name: Merlie

texts.en:
Merlie is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a 'buy and sell' fish business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to buy additional boxes of fish to sell for her business.

Merlie has been in this business for six years. Merlie earns more income from her general store and raising pigs.

Merlie has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional boxes of fish to sell

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Marilou works hard to support her family. She has a 'buy and sell' egg business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling vegetables. Marilou is borrowing PHP 28,000 through NWTF to  purchase additional trays of eggs to sell for her business.

Marilou has been sustaining her business activities through her past 19 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional trays of eggs to sell

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Rowena works hard to support her family. She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from her general store. Rowena is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to buy fishing materials for her business.

Rowena has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials for her business

loans.name: Myra

texts.en:
Myra is 33 years old and married with two children. She works hard to provide for her family. She buys and sells beauty products in the Philippines and requested a PHP 28,000 loan through NWTF to buy beauty products to sell.

Myra has borrowed and repaid 14 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the beauty products business for six years and also earns an income from a beauty parlor.

Myra aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy beauty products to sell

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline owns a food stall business, where neighbours and town dwellers are her customers. She faces a major challenge of fluctuations in the number of clients she has, hence spoilage of goods leading to losses.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase a stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour and cooking fat for sale. She dreams of expanding to a modern café business and she appreciates the support.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour and cooking fat for sale.

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi operates a cafe, selling food to passersby and neighbours. She cited seasonality and theft as her major challenges. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase two bundles of wheat flour and cooking oil and maize flour for food preparation. Her dream is to see her children get a better education and become important people in society. She appreciates the support given.

loans.use: to purchase two bundles of wheat flour and cooking oil and maize flour for food preparation.

loans.name: Umazi

texts.en:
Umazi is a widowed woman and has been blessed with five children who attend school. She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

She operates a poultry selling business, which has been operational for over three years. She mentioned disease outbreaks causing losses as a challenge in the business and she dreams of becoming a wholesaler of poultry in the future. 

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase chicks and poultry feed. She joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and poultry feed.

loans.name: Melva De Jesús

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Balzar se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia San Placido del cantón Portoviejo, este lugar se lo conoce por su gente amable y trabajadora que en su mayoría se dedican a las faenas del campo.
