En este lugar vive la señora Melva, tiene 59 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen 8 hijos mayores de edad, tres de ellos aun viven con ella. Su esposo se dedica a la agricultura.

Doña Melva tiene una tienda de víveres en su casa,  allí vende todo tipo de productos, desde víveres hasta productos de bazar y también de papelería,  trabaja todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, sus hijos y su esposo le ayudan en su trabajo cuando están  desocupados, pero por lo general ella la que mas pasa en su negocio. Tiene más de 40 años con su tienda la cual le ha dado muchos beneficios y le ha permitido ganar algo para las necesidades de sus hijos cuando estos estaban pequeños.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, entre otros productos de primera necesidad. Lleva 13 años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la ayuda que le dan estos créditos. 

Su sueño es seguir adelante por el bien de su familia.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Balzar" meets every 15 days in San Placido parish in the canton of Portoviejo.  This is a place that is known for its friendly and hardworking people, who mainly work in the fields.

This is where Melva, 59, lives.  She is married, and she and her husband have 8 grown children.  Three of them still live with her.  Melva's husband works in agriculture.

Melva has a grocery store in her house where she sells all types of products, from groceries to general merchandise, and even stationery.  She works every day from 6am until 8pm, and sometimes even later.  She's had her store for more than 40 years. It has given her a lot of benefits, and enabled her to earn something to meet the needs of her children when they were young.

She will use this loan to stock her store with more products.  She will buy rice, sugar, cooking oil, detergents, and other consumer staples.  She's been with her communal bank for 13 years, and she likes it because of the help that is provided with these loans.  

Melva's dream is to continue ahead with the business for the sake of her family.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, cooking oil, detergents, and other consumer staples

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa es una señorita de 23  años de edad, vive junto a sus padres en el Barrio Sanquichey, San Antonio Palopó, Sololá.  
Es una persona emprendedora que por falta de empleo formal acorde a su profesión  eligió la labor de elaboración de bordados a máquina, lo cual realiza en su vivienda; ella tiene dos años de estar realizando esta actividad lo cual lo hace con mucho optimismo y creatividad y con los ingresos que obtiene aporta a cubrir los gastos familiares. Este trabajo lo aprendió de su madre, porque ella se dedicaba a esa labor por tal razón decidió seguirle los pasos. 
Ella ha observado que los bordados que elabora tienen una gran demanda por lo que desea invertir más capital en su negocio, solicitando un préstamo de  Q 3,500.00 para comprar una máquina industrial para poder producir más bordados y así tener mejores ganancias.
Los sueños de Teresa es ayudar a sus padres y también poder expandir sus ventas al mercado local.
texts.en:
Teresa is a 23 year-old woman who lives with her parents in the Sanquichey neighborhood of San Antonio Palopó, Sololá.  She is an enterprising person who, due to a lack of formal employment in her profession, chose to make embroidered pieces using a sewing machine.  She does this work in her home.  She's been doing this work for 2 years, and she works with a lot of optimism and creativity.  With the income she earns, she contributes to the household expenses.  

Teresa learned how to do this work from her mother.  As her mother was doing this work, she decided to follow in her footsteps.  Teresa has observed that there is a lot of demand for the embroidered pieces that she makes, and so she wants to invest more capital in her business.  She is requesting a loan of 3,500 Guatemalan quetzales that she will use to buy an industrial sewing machine so that she can produce more embroidery and thereby obtain greater earnings.  Teresa's dreams are to help her parents and also to be able to expand her sales to the local market.

loans.use: to buy an industrial sewing machine

loans.name: Kwekwe

texts.en:
Kwekwe is a married woman and has been blessed with seven children, all of whom attend school. Together with her husband, she owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

For ten years, Kwekwe has operated a business selling meat goats, buying and fattening them from home to sell at a profit to slaughter operators. She dreams of expanding her business to accommodate the whole town in the future. With this 10,000 Kenyan shilling loan, she wants to purchase goats for fattening and later resale. Kwekwe decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase goats for fattening and later resale

loans.name: Lolo Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe LOLO ont en moyenne 41 ans, 6 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à LAFIABOUGOU  un des quartiers de la ville de SAN (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente de condiments alimentaires,  des articles divers de boutique, d'habits, de la restauration,etc.
les femmes du groupe LOLO sont à leur 5 eme  prêt solidaire. AWA 1 ère femme debout de la gauche  vers la droite sur la photo  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des pièces de pagnes  wax.
 Elles s’approvisionnent à SAN et les villages environnants. Elles effectuent ses ventes, sur place à SAN, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de17 500FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the "Lolo" group are on average 41 years old with six children and all live in traditional extended households in Lafiabougou, one of the areas of the city of San (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).
These women know each other through family links and run businesses buying and selling food condiments, various general store items, and clothing, as well as preparing and selling food, etc.
The women of the Lolo group are on their fifth solidarity (group) loan. Awa, the woman standing all the way on the left in the photo, intends to use her loan to buy sets of pagnes wax (a type of brightly-printed clothing worn in West Africa).
They get their supplies in San and the neighbouring towns. They make their sales on the spot in San to a clientele composed of women and men.
They foresee realizing an average monthly profit of 17,500 FCFA, which will be used to pay for expenses related to health, nutrition, and schooling, with the remainder being reinvested in their businesses.

loans.use: To buy clothing for resale.

loans.name: Bédériatou

texts.fr: Madame Bédériatou est mère au foyer. Elle est âgée de 31ans et a 02 enfants en charge. Son conjoint est peintre –bâtiment. Pour bien jouer son rôle de femme au foyer, Elle exerce l’activité de la vente des produits cosmétiques depuis 2002. Son approvisionnement se fait à Lomé chez les grossistes de produits cosmétiques et sa vente se réalise de façon ambulante. Sa clientèle augmente de jour en jour et ne disposant pas d’assez de moyens financiers pour répondre à leurs besoins, elle sollicite de WAGES un troisième montant pour pouvoir se ravitailler en produits cosmétiques. Elle veut agrandir l’activité, diversifier les marchandises, installer un point de vente fixe et assurer les besoins primaires de la famille.
texts.en: Ms. Bédériatou is a homemaker. She is 31 years old and has two children in her care. Her husband is a building painter. To better support her role as a homemaker, she has run a business selling cosmetics since 2002. She gets her supplies from cosmetics wholesalers in Lomé and makes her sales door-to-door. Her clientele is growing from day to day, and because she does not have enough financial means to respond to their needs, she is seeking a third loan through WAGES in order to be able to replenish her supply of cosmetics. She wants to expand her business, diversify her merchandise, set up a permanent sales point, and ensure her family's basic needs.

loans.use: to buy cosmetic products.

loans.name: Sara

texts.es:
La señora Sara tiene 56 años de edad vive en pareja  hace 33 años con el señor Cesar de  57 años, la pareja tiene un solo hijo de 31 años de edad y que ya formó su propio hogar y vive en forma independiente.
La señora Sara cuenta con dos vehículos en las cuales ayudado por su esposo y un chofer particular realiza fletes y acarrea su propia caña dulce  a la fabrica de la ciudad para su procesamiento, se dedica a este rubro desde hace 7 años, y con ello está ayudando a su marido y cubriendo los gastos y necesidades de la casa.
Ella  solicita el préstamo para la compra de cubiertas nuevas para poner en condiciones su vehículo y poder realizar su trabajo sin tantos problemas,  que le permita asegurar su ingreso mensual.
texts.en:
Sara is 56 years old and has been married 33 years to 57 year old Cesar. The couple has only a 31 year old son who now has his own home and lives independently from his parents. 
Sara has two vehicles in which with help from her husband and a private chauffeur hauls cargo and transports her own sugar cane to the factory in the city for processing. She has been in this business for 7 years, and with it is helping her husband and covering the household expenses and necessities. 
She seeks a loan to buy new covers to use on her vehicles during bad weather and be able to do her work without  many problems, which will thus ensure her monthly income.

loans.use: to buy covers for vehicles

loans.name: Delfin

texts.es:
El señor Delfin tiene 64 años , está casado hace 42 años con la señora Arsenia de 59 años, el matrimonio tiene 4 hijos de los cuales 3 ya están casados viven en forma independiente y el  menor de todos de 19 años vive con su padre y está cursando el 1er año de la  universidad y la idea de sus padres es que pueda terminar sin inconvenientes sus estudios.
El señor Delfin se dedica a la compra y ventas de productos variados como ser  chorizo, pollos, cebollas, arroz, aceite, manteca desde hace 23 años y le surte a los grandes negocios de la ciudad como supermercado y restaurante.
Solicita este préstamo para la  compra de arroz, pollos, verduras y demás, debido a que cuenta con mucho pedidos y de esta forma poder cumplir con todos los pedidos que cuenta.-
texts.en:
Delfin is 64 years old, married for 42 years to 59 year old Arsenia. They have 4 children, 3 are married and live independently and the youngest, 19 years old, lives at home and is in the first year of studying at the university and his parents want him to be able to finish his studies without any inconveniences.
Delfin has worked buying and selling a variety of products such as sausage, chicken, onions, rice, oil, butter for 23 years and he stocks large businesses in the city such as supermarkets and restaurants. He seeks this loan to buy rice, chicken, vegetables and other items, as he has many orders and in this way can fulfill all the orders that he has.

loans.use: to buy rice, chickens, vegetables and other items.

loans.name: María Divina

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Balzar se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia San Placido del cantón Portoviejo, este lugar se lo conoce por su gente amable y trabajadora que en su mayoría se dedican  a las faenas del campo.

En este lugar vive la señora María, tiene 61 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen 4 hijos mayores de edad e independientes. Su esposo se dedica a la agricultura.
 
Doña María tiene una tienda de víveres en su casa,  allí vende todo tipo de productos, desde víveres hasta productos de Avon y Yanbal (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas), trabaja todos los días desde las 06h00 hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, su esposo le ayuda en su trabajo cuando está  desocupado más que todo en las noches y fines de semana. Tiene 18 años con su tienda la misma que la empezó con el primer crédito que recibió del banco.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar víveres y productos Avon y Yanbal. Esta desde el inicio en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque gracias a los  créditos empezó su negocio con el cual salen adelante. 

Su sueño es seguir aumentando su negocio.
texts.en:
The Balzar communal bank meets every two weeks in San Placido parish, in Puerto Viejo canton. This place is known for its friendly and hard-working people, the majority of whom are engaged in farming.  

In this place lives Maria. She is 61 years old, married and has four adult children, who are independent. Her husband farms.
 
María has a grocery store in her home. There she sells all kinds of products, from groceries to Avon and Yanbal products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfume and women's accessories).  She works every day from 6 a.m. until 8 p.m., and sometimes later.  Her husband helps her in her work when he is free, especially at night and on weekends. She has had her store for 18 years, and started it with the first loan she received from the communal bank.

She is going to use this loan to further stock her store. She is going to buy groceries, as well as Avon and Yanbal products. She has been in the communal bank since the beginning, and likes it because thanks to the loans, she started her business which is allowing them to move forward. Her dream is to continue increasing her business.

loans.use: To buy groceries, as well as Avon and Yanbal products.

loans.name: La Amistad 2 Group

texts.es:
El grupo llamado La Amistad 2 está en su ciclo número 6 del programa de comité de mujeres. El comité es un grupo muy unido y tiene un excelente comportamiento de pago. Ellas están muy entusiasmadas de seguir aprendiendo y creciendo.
La Sra. Liz, una de las integrantes, quien se dedica a la venta de prendas de ropa interior. Por medio de su trabajo ayuda a sus familiares, ayudándoles por medio de los ingresos que gana.
Ella solicita de este crédito para la compra de ropas interiores, para damas, caballeros y niños, lo que le ayudará a  concretar su plan de negocio, el cual le ayudará a mejorar sus ingresos.
En la foto del grupo estan 15 mujeres, ya que el grupo esta integrado por 15 mujeres pero solo 13 estan quitando un crédito en esta oportunidad.
texts.en:
The group called  La Amistad 2 (Friendship 2) is in its 6th loan cycle of the women's committee program. The committee is a very united group and has an excellent repayment record. They are very enthusiastic to keep learning and growing.
Liz, one of the members, sells underwear. Through her work she helps her friends, helping them through her income she earns.
She seeks a loan to buy underwear for women, men, and children. This will help her solidify her business plan, which will help her increase her income.
In the group photo are 15 women, as the group is made up of 15 women but only 13 are receiving a loan in this particular opportunity.

loans.use: to buy underwear for women, men and children.

loans.name: Némè

texts.fr: Némè a 45 ans, elle habite à Lomé avec son mari et leurs enfants. Le mari de Némè est militaire. Elle exerce depuis 02ans la profession de revendeuse. Elle vend toutes sortes d'objet en plastique et des pagnes sur un étalage. Némè son souhait est d'acheter d'avantage d'objets en plastique et de pagnes afin d'agrandir son activité. C'est pour cela, elle sollicite un crédit dans notre institution(WAGES). Elle espère que les profits réalisés lui permettront de diversifier sa marchandise et d'ouvrir une boutique. Sa priorité reste cependant d'assurer les besoins primaires de sa famille.
texts.en: Némè is 45 years old and lives in Lomé with her husband and their children. Némè's husband is a soldier. She has run a retail business for two years and sells all sorts of plasticware at a display stall. Némè's wish is to buy more plasticware and pagnes (brightly-printed West African clothing) to expand her business. To do so, she is seeking a loan from our institution (WAGES). She hopes that the profits she will earn will allow her to diversify her merchandise and to open a store. However, her priority is still to ensure that her family's basic needs are met.

loans.use: to buy plasticware

loans.name: Sahadatou

texts.fr: Ayant pour mari un employé dans une société de la place, Mme Sahadatou âgée de 47ans et mère de famille est revendeuse de profession et vend des produits d’alimentation générale à domicile et au marché. Son troisième crédit qu’elle sollicite dans notre institution(WAGES) lui servira à acheter des produits d’alimentation générale (riz, huile végétale, sucre, spaghetti) à Lomé. Elle voudrait devenir grossiste et aider sa famille à mieux s’épanouir. Il y a de cela 10ans qu’elle est dans cette activité.
texts.en: With a husband who works at a local company, Ms. Sahadatou is a 47-year-old mother of a family and works as a retailer selling general food items at home and at the market. The third loan she is seeking from our institution (WAGES) will enable her to buy general food items (rice, vegetable oil, sugar, spaghetti) in Lomé. She would like to become a wholesaler and help her family thrive more. She has been in this business for the past ten years.

loans.use: to buy groceries.

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en:
Mwaka is a married woman with eight kids. She lives at her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a kiosk (small shop) business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Her potential customers are neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business, and she dreams of establishing a wholesale shop business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of 30,000 KES (Kenyan shillings), she wants to purchase stock of wheat flour, maize flour, beans and rice. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of wheat flour, maize flour and beans.

loans.name: Chari

texts.en:
Chari is a married woman and lives with her husband and 12 children. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past 10 years, she has operated a charcoal-selling business. She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation. She dreams of expanding her business to become a wholesale supplier of charcoal in the village. 

With the 30,000 KES she wants to purchase bundles of charcoal for resale. She decided to join to Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Umazi

texts.en:
Umazi is a married woman who has been blessed with six children, all of whom attend school.  Together with her husband, they own a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. 

For two years, she has operated a goat meat selling business, buying and fattening them for sale at a profit from home to slaughter operators. She dreams of expanding her business to accommodate the whole town in the future.

With the 20,000 KES she wants to purchase goats for fattening and later resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase goats for fattening and later resale.

loans.name: Naome

texts.en:
Naome operates a clothes-selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of stiff competition in her business. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of 50,000 KES she wants to purchase two bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and she appreciates for the support and also for the previous loan that helped her to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase two bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en:
Chizi is married and has three children all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has no electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past seven years, she has owned a business of weaving baskets, where neighbours and town dwellers are her customers. She faces a major challenge of fluctuations in prices of the baskets.

With the 40,000 KES she wants to purchase stock weaving materials for making baskets to sell. She dreams of expanding to a modern basket shop in the business.

loans.use: to purchase stock weaving materials for making baskets to sell

loans.name: Alima

texts.en:
Alima is married and has seven children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past seven years, she has owned a food stall business, where she sells to neighbours and town dwellers. She faces a major challenge of fluctuations in number of clients, thus allowing perishable goods to go bad, leading to losses.

With the 50,000 KES she wants to purchase stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour, and cooking fat for food preparation. She dreams of expanding to a modern café with her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour, and cooking fat for food preparation.

loans.name: Julienne Vivianne

texts.fr: Julienne est une jeune femme de 37 ans mariée mère de 6 enfants dont l'age varie entre 3 et 21 ans, cinq de ses enfants vont encore à l'école. Elle est commerçante dans un marché de la place où elle commercialise les arachides, l'huile et les noix de palme depuis 06 ans. satisfaite de son premier crédit, elle sollicite à nouveau un second pour faire face aux difficultés auxquelles elle est confrontée. , elle a un problème parce que la vente en détail rapporte peu et voudrait diversifier son activité. par conséquent,elle aimerait augmenter ses stocks de marchandises en achetant les arachides en sacs, les tubercules et le mais.ce qui lui évitera les ruptures de stocks, et lui permettra d'augmenter ses bénefices. Elle réinvestira une partie du bénéfice dans son activité pour acheter encore plus de marchandises,et économiser le reste pour aider son époux avec une partie de la scolarisation de leurs enfants.
texts.en: Julienne is a young married woman, aged 37, and mother of six children whose ages range from 3 to 21. Five of her children still attend school. She is a vendor at the local market, where she has specialized in selling peanuts and palm nut oil for six years. Satisfied with her first loan, she is now seeking a second in order to face the difficulties that confront her: she has a problem because retail sales bring in little money, and she wants to diversify her business. To do so, she would like to increase her stock of merchandise by buying sacks of peanuts, tubers, and maize, which will allow her to avoid stock shortages and increase her profits. She will reinvest a portion of her profit in her business to buy even more merchandise and save the rest to help her husband with a portion of their children's school fees.

loans.use: to buy sacks of peanuts and several barrels of palm oil

loans.name: Cora

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Cora works hard to support her family. She has a business buying and selling recycled materials in the Philippines and also earns additional income from a motorcycle transport business and farming vegetables. Cora is borrowing 14,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) through NWTF to purchase more recycled materials to sell for her business.

Cora has been sustaining her business activities with her past 17 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money to expand her business and send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more recycled materials to sell

loans.name: Kely Senayda

texts.es:
kely de 21  años de edad es madre soltera, de un niño de 3 años de edad. Procede de una familia de cinco hermanos quienes se fueron a vivir con su padre. Desde pequeña ella se creció con una tía, pues su madre emigro hacia los Estados Unidos y la dejo desde niña a cargo de su tía. 

Ella inicio hace ya un año y medio en la venta de ropa (para niños/as, adultos y mayores de edad, a la vez vende, productos de lencería y chinas para todas las edades), este trabajo lo aprendió gracias a su tío quien le inculco a velar por sus propios ingresos y para sostener al niño, pues ella vive solo con él. Antes ella estudiaba en el municipio, donde termino la educación media. Hoy en día su negocio le es rentable y de ahí obtiene sus ingresos económicos para salir adelante.

la ropa que compra para el comercio la adquiere en una ciudad y también le trae ropa y calzado su tío. para ir a comprar lo hace acompañado de una amiga en transporte urbano una hora de viaje para llegar al destino.

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para comprar 4 docenas de pantalones, el cual en promedio invertirá $400.00, $300.00 en la compra de camisas (para hombres de todas las edades) y blusas para damas y  $200.00 en la compra de sandalias, chinas para todas las edades, el resto lo necesita para cancelar el viaje hasta el lugar donde realiza la compra de la mercadería.  Necesita tener mercadería para la temporada de vacaciones en el país pues es un periodo donde hay bastante demanda de ropa. Pues ahorita no posee mucha oferta para los clientes, ella ya tiene varios clientes en diferentes comunidades, pues ella también sale a vender por días a las comunidades cercanas.

En el futuro desea, tener un negocio ya bien establecido con su propio local y distribuir al mayoreo, a largo plazo planea comprar su propio terreno donde hacer una casa para su hijo y ella.
texts.en:
Kely is 21 years old and is a single mother of a 3-year-old boy. She is from a family of five siblings who went to live with their dad. Since she was young, she grew up with an aunt, since her mother emigrated to the United States and left her since she was a child with her aunt. 

A year and a half ago, she started selling clothing (for children, adults, and senior citizens; at the same times she sells undergarments and shoes). She learned this work thanks to her uncle who taught her to safeguard her income and to raise her son, since she lives alone with him. Before she studied in the city, where she finished middle school. Today her business is profitable and from it she obtains economic income to move forward. 

The clothing that she buys for sale, she acquires in a city and her uncle also brings her clothing and shoes. To go shopping, she accompanies a friend on urban transportation, which is one hour to arrive at the destination. 

The loan that she is requesting from Fundacion Campo is to purchase 4 dozen pairs of pants, in which she will invest an average of $400; $300 in the purchase of shirts (for men of all ages) and women's blouses and $200 on the purchase of sandals, shoes for all ages; the rest she needs to pay for the trip to the location where she purchases the merchandise. She needs to have the merchandise for the vacation season in the country, since it is a period where there is a big demand for clothing. Now she does not have much to offer customers, and she already has various customers in different communities, and she also goes to sell in the close communities. 

In the future, she hopes to have a well-established business with her own location and to distribute wholesale. In the long term, she plans to buy her own land to make a house for her son and her.

loans.use: to purchase 4 dozen pairs of pants, in which she will invest an average of $400; $300 in the purchase of shirts (for men of all ages) and women's blouses and $200 on the purchase of sandals, shoes for all ages; the rest she needs to pay for the trip to the location where she purchases the merchandise.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business selling ice cream in the Philippines. Gloria has been in this business for nine years. She earns additional income from a general store.

Gloria has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She is borrowing 28,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) through NWTF to purchase additional ingredients for her ice cream business. She dreams of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients for her ice cream business

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita is 50 years old and married with two children.

Amelita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 27,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy additional items like rice, eggs, soap, shampoo, groceries, etc., to sell.

Amelita has borrowed and repaid 18 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 20 years and also earns an income from food vending and raisng pigs.

Amelita aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items like rice, eggs, soap, shampoo, groceries, etc., to sell.

loans.name: Amor

texts.en:
Amor is 47 years old and married with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Amor has a videoke rental business in the Philippines. Amor requested a 21,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan amount through NWTF to buy an additional videoke machine. She earns additional income from a general store.

Amor has been in this business for seven years. In the future, Amor would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional videoke machine.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn is 34 years old and married with five children, three of whom are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Analyn has a fish-vending business in the Philippines. Analyn requested a 11,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan amount through NWTF to buy additional fish like lapu-lapu, tilapia, galunggong, etc., to sell.

Analyn has been in this business for 17 years. In the future, Analyn would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional fish like lapu-lapu, tilapia, galunggong, etc., to sell.

loans.name: Consolita

texts.en:
Consolita is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business selling native products such as brooms in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 25,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy more stock of native products to sell for her business.

Consolita has been in this business for 15 years. Consolita earns more income from a general store and from selling ready-to-wear clothing. 

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build up her businesses.

Consolita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more stock of native products such as brooms to sell.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 46 years old and has six children. Evelyn is married and has two children who are in school.

Evelyn is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. Evelyn requested a 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Evelyn has been raising pigs for 10 years now, and has borrowed 12 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Evelyn would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Haide

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Haide works hard to support her family.

She has a buying and selling of fruits business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from motorcycle transport and raising pigs. Haide is borrowing 10,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy additional fruits to sell for her fruits business.

Haide has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional fruits to sell.

loans.name: Tura

texts.en:
Tura is 60 years old and married with two children.

Tura works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 17,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock like canned goods, soap, eggs, noodles, etc.

Tura has borrowed and repaid 18 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for six years and also earns an income from buying and selling charcoal.

Tura aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock like canned goods, soap, eggs, noodles, etc.

loans.name: Fatimata

texts.fr: Madame Fatimata est une femme âgée de 52 ans qui vie aux environs du guichet. Elle est mariée et mère de famille. Elle évolue dans le commerce depuis 3ans, Fatimata commence sa journée à 10h pour terminer à 20h. Elle sollicite ce prêt d’un montant de 300.000F pour acheter des tissus, chaussures, et bazins qu’elle revende au marché. Elle n’a pas de charges particulières. A l’avenir elle souhaite diversifier son activité et augmenter ses revenus afin d'améliorer la condition de vie de sa famille
texts.en:
Madame Fatimata is a woman of 52 who lives near the branch office. She is married and the mother of a family. She has been working as a merchant for three years. 

Fatimata begins her workday at 10 am and ends it at 8 pm. She is asking for a loan in the amount of 300,000 francs to buy cloth, shoes and damask cloth (for dyeing) that she resells at the market. She does not have any particular responsibilities. In future, she would like to diversify her business and grow her income so as to improve living conditions for her family.

loans.use: to buy cloth, damask cloth, and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Mody Group

texts.en: Mody is a group composed of three Filipino ladies who work as housekeepers for Lebanese families. They decided to join hands and form the group in order to support each other financially. Cabanilla is the leader and featured member of the group. She is a 49 year-old married mother of three children, standing on the left of the picture. Her husband is currently unemployed, which means that they depend on her revenue in order to live through the month. She decided to form the group in order to be able to cover the tuition fees of her children. As for the other group members, Evelyn is standing at the center of the picture while Marivel is standing on the right of the picture.

loans.use: to cover the tuition fees of her children.

loans.name: Ndèye

texts.fr:
Madame Ndèye, une femme de 51ans, mariée et mère de sept enfants évolue dans l’agriculture depuis des années. Elle appuie son époux dans les travaux champêtres. Elle est une cliente nouvellement inscrite au guichet d’IMCEC et elle demande un crédit de 100000F CFA pour pouvoir acheter des semences et de l’engrais dans le but de préparer l’hivernage.
Avec les revenus de l’activité ils gèrent avec son mari, les charges familiales et les besoins quotidiens des membres de la famille.
Puisse qu’elle possède d’autres terres, elle aimerait les exploiter si elle a les moyens, pour cela elle compte sur l’appui de l’IMCEC pour le financement de ses projets.
texts.en:
Madame Ndèye, a woman of 51, married and the mother of seven children, has been working in agriculture for years. She gives her husband a hand with farm work. She is a recently registered client of the IMCEC branch office and she is asking for a loan of 100,000 F CFA to be able to buy seeds and fertilizer so as to prepare for the rainy season. 

With the income from the activities she manages with her husband, (they cover) household expenses and daily needs of family members. Since she has other plots of land that she would like to cultivate if she had the means, she is counting on the support of IMCEC to finance these projects.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer to prepare for this growing season.

loans.name: Maimouna

texts.fr: La  dame  Maimouna  est   une   femme   mariée   qui   vit   au   Sénégal.  Elle  s’active  dans   le  secteur   du   commerce   depuis  20 ans.   Son  activité   consiste   à  vendre  du  charbon et  des  légumes.   Elle  a déjà remboursé 3 crédits antérieurs  au sein du guichet de l’UIMCEC ou il est membre. Il sollicite a nouveau un prêt de 50 000 frs prévu pour l’achat de charbon et de légumes destinés  a la vente. Son  financement l’aidera à développer d’avantage son activité de commerce, améliorer le niveau de ses bénéfices pour mieux prendre en charge la nourriture de sa famille. Son soucis est de parvenir a améliorer les conditions alimentaires de sa famille et d’acquérir un toit dans le futur.
texts.en:
Madame  Maimouna  is a married woman who lives in Senegal. She has been working in commerce for 20 years. Her activity is selling charcoal and vegetables. She has already reimbursed three prior loans at the branch office of UIMCEC where she is a member. 

She is asking for another loan of 50,000 francs to use to buy charcoal and vegetables for resale. This financial support will help her to develop her commercial activity and grow her profit so that she can feed her family better. Her concern is to manage to improve her family's nutrition and in future, get a roof.

loans.use: to buy charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en: Jean works hard to support her family. She is married and has a buy-and-sell banana business in the Philippines. Jean has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional bananas to sell. She has been in this business for three years now. In the future, Jean would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional bananas to sell.

loans.name: Valbona

texts.en:
Valbona is a 41-year-old villager from the rural southeast whose two children are twelve and fifteen years old.  Both attend the public school in their village. According to our poverty measures, almost 100% of residents in their village fall below the poverty line of $1.25/day. The majority of them can barely be eligible for a very small loan from VFA, with other financial institutions completely rejecting them. This is why VFA, in collaboration with World Vision, implemented the integrated projects in an attempt to tackle the poverty in this region. World Vision covers the interest rates on behalf of clients and VFA offers the loan and other technical help.

Valbona has been in the agricultural activity for the past six years and this loan of 200,000 Albanian lek (ALL) will help her buy corn seeds and some pesticides for the plants. She expressed to the loan officer that she is on cloud nine about the opportunity and wants to thank all parties involved in making it happen.

loans.use: to buy corn seeds for planting and pesticides for the seedlings

loans.name: Jossie

texts.en: Jossie works hard to support her family. She is married and has a used clothes selling business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional bundles of used clothes to sell. She has been in this business for five years now. In the future, Jossie would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional bundles of used clothes to sell.

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Madame Aminata est une femme mariée de 38 ans et mère de 5 enfants. Elle vit avec ses enfants chez son époux dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de Bougouni. Ayant abandonnée l’école dès à son jeune âge à cause surtout de la pauvreté de ses parents, elle décida de mener des activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente des pagnes et d’habits. Nantie de 8 ans d’expériences, elle est très sollicitée et appréciée à Bougouni. Après avoir correctement remboursés ses quatre précédents prêts, elle est à son cinquième qui sera utilisé pour acheter 10 complets pour hommes et 10 pièces des pagnes. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako (Capitale de la République du Mali). Ses marchandises sont vendues à la maison et dans les différents quartiers de Bougouni. 
Elle compte réaliser  avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000FCFA, qui servira à aider les parents, appuyer son époux dans les charges de la famille,  payer les intérêts du prêt et à agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Aminata is a married woman, 38 years old and the mother of five children. She lives with her ​​children and her husband in the North Hérémakono district of Bougouni.

Having quit school at an early age mainly due to her parent's poverty, she decided to undertake income-generating activities such as the purchase and sale of pagnes (colorful West-African fabric) and clothing. With over 8 years' experience, she is highly sought after and appreciated in Bougouni.

Having successfully repaid her four previous loans, this is her fifth which will be used to buy 10 sets of men's clothing and 10 pagnes. She resupplies in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). Her goods are sold from her home and in various districts of Bougouni.

She intends to achieve monthly profits of 50,000 FCFA, which will serve to help her parents, assist her husband with family expenses, pay interest on the loan and expand her business.

loans.use: Buy clothing

loans.name: Bassem

texts.en: Bassem is a 33 year-old married father of one child. He is employed in an agriculture company, which is the only financial resource for the family. However, this income is very low and insufficient to provide for his household. He decided to contact Al Majmoua to acquire a loan in order to purchase construction materials for the maintenance of his house. As for the future, Bassem wishes to expand his own farming business.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials for the maintenance of his house.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en: Luz is 27-years-old and married with six children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Luz is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy additional feed and vitamins for her pigs. Luz has been raising pigs for three years and also earns additional income from buying and selling rice. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward is a married man aged 32 years and has two children aged six and two years old. He provides motorcycle services and has been in this business for three years. He earns an income of KES 12,000 monthly.

He has borrowed his second term loan of KES 50,000 from KADET LTD and intends to use this amount to expand his current business by purchasing another motorcycle. The profits he earns will be used to pay the school fees of his children and also repay the loan.

His dream is to live a happy life with his family and expand his current business.

loans.use: To expand his motorcycle transport business.

loans.name: Nolambay

texts.en:
Nolambay is a resident of Taguig, Philippines. She is 50 years old and happily married to Moamer, who works as driver. God has blessed them with loving children. Life is indeed hard. But, by the grace of God, they were able to raise their children well and they are helping each other in working for their family.

Nolambay owns a variety store. This is a small store that can be owned by anyone in the community and the store is just connected to or just inside their houses. This is where you can buy a sachet of shampoo or conditioner, a bar of soap, PHP 5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg, and others. She gets her product from a wholesaler at a lower price and resell it per piece for a higher price to have profit. Her regular customers are her neighbors, passersby and the people in the community. She earns PHP 300 a day.

To be able to expand her inventory, she is requesting a PHP 14,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. This loan will be a great help for her to add more products to her store.

Nolambay hopes to expand her business and dreams that her family will have a good life. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en: Rosalia is 37-years-old and married with three children who are in school. She works very hard to provide for them. Rosalia runs a fish vending business in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional fish like bangus, lapu-lapu, tambakul, etc. to sell. She has been in this business for 15 years and earns additional income from a motorcycle transport and pig fattening business. She successfully repaid her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her businesses. In the future, Rosalia would like to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional fish like bangus, lapu-lapu, tambakul, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Valentina works hard to support her family. She has a business making and selling dried fish in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a motorcycle transport business. Valentina is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy additional fish to process into dried fish for her business.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her past 18 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her to attain her dream to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional fish to process into dried fish.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines. She is borrowing through NWTF to buy spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle for her business. She has been in this business for 10 years. Yolanda earns additional income from fishing.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

loans.name: Ha

texts.en: Ha is 36 years old. She has a child who is studying in the fifth grade. She is a widow. She sells vegetables and fruits in a market. Her income is about 6,000,000 VND per month. She has done this job for 10 years. Her challenge in work is transporting goods by motorbike because it is difficult and risky. Her dream is to build a more beautiful house. This loan is one of the steps to help her reach this dream. She can gain earnings and save her profit for her family’s life. Ha is a hardworking woman and has a passion for business. She has participated in SEDA’s microfinance program since 2011. In the last loan cycle, she borrowed 7,392,000 VND and repaid it on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 7,840,000 VND to build her house.

loans.use: to build her house.

loans.name: Rodelyn

texts.en:
Rodelyn is 35 years old and married.  

Rodelyn is in the agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines. Rodelyn requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Rodelyn has been raising pigs for five years now, and has borrowed seven times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

Rodelyn would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Rodilyn

texts.en:
Rodilyn is a married woman with two children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Rodilyn is 34 years old and has one child who is in school.

Rodilyn has a business making native bags in the Philippines. Rodilyn requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase raw materials for making native bags.

Rodilyn has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, Rodilyn would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for making native bags

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling vegetables in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 17,000 through NWTF to purchase additional vegetables to sell for her buying and selling vegetables business.

Nancy has been in this business for 19 years. Nancy earns more income from food vending.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting an additional loan to further build her buying and selling vegetable and food vending business.

Nancy has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional vegetables to sell

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
Rachel is married and has kids who attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a motorcycle transport business door-to-door. In addition, she operates a poultry farming business, which earns her another source of income.  She sells to restaurant operators and local neighbours. Her major challenge is the high cost of transportation to her place of operation.

With the KSH 50,000, she wants to add to her savings and purchase another motorcycle. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to add to her savings and purchase another motorcycle.

loans.name: Kadia  Yacouba

texts.fr:
Madame Kadia Yacouba est une femme mariée de 38 ans et mère de 5 enfants. Elle vit avec son époux et ses enfants dans le quartier Hérémakono Centre de Bougouni. Ayant vite abandonnée l’école en classe de 5ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien), alors elle décida d’apprendre des activités génératrices de revenus. 
Madame Kadia faisait de la restauration à la gare routière de Bougouni pendant 3 ans, qu’elle arrêta à cause d’une maladie qui ne la permet  pas de supporter la chaleur, c’est ainsi  qu’elle décide de spécialisée dans le commerce de pagnes, des habits et des chaussures, activités apprise auprès de sa sœur . Avec une expérience de 9 ans; elle maitrise cette activité. 
Elle est à son troisième prêt avec Soro Yiriwaso et tous ses 2 prêts précédents sont bien remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt  3 pièces de pagnes, 10 complets d’habits pour femme et 1 douzaine de chaussures composée de plusieurs catégories.  Elle s’approvisionne au Burkina Faso et parfois à Bamako. Ses articles sont vendus à la maison et dans les différents quartiers de Bougouni.
Elle compte réaliser  avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000 FCFA. Avec ce bénéfice elle compte agrandir son activité, subvenir à ses besoins et payé les intérêts du prêt.
texts.en:
Mrs. Kadia Yacouba is a married woman, 38 years of age and the mother of five children. She lives with her ​​husband and children in the Hérémakono Centre neighborhood  in Bougouni. She soon quit school in the 5th grade (Malian education system), and decided to learn income-generating activities.

Mrs. Kadia catered at the Bougouni bus station for 3 years, and stopped because of an illness that did not allow her to withstand heat. She then decided to specialize in trading pagnes (colorful West-African fabric), sets of clothing and shoes, which she learned from her sister. With nine years' experience, she now masters this activity.

She is on her third loan with Soro Yiriwaso and her two previous loans have been repaid. She intends to use the loan to buy three lengths of pagnes, 10 full sets of women's clothing and one dozen pairs of different kinds of footwear. She resupplies in Burkina Faso and sometimes in Bamako. Her products are sold from her home and in various districts of Bougouni.

She intends to achieve monthly profits of 40,000 FCFA, with which she plans to expand her business, meet her own needs and pay interest on the loan.

loans.use: Buy pagnes, sets of clothing and footwear

loans.name: Ibonde Tweyimukye Group

texts.en:
Christopher used the previous loan to buy general merchandise to sell. He is aged 35, trades in produce, and raises goats. He is a member of the above-mentioned group where each member guarantees the other in accessing a loan. Christopher is a very hardworking man and lives with his family in Fort Portal, Uganda. His profits allow him to pay the school fees for his children. 

In order to raise money to meet his family's daily expenses, he used his profits from raising goats to start a retail shop and has since reaped tangible benefits. He names price fluctuation and inflation as his primary business challenges. His main business plan is eventually to own a wholesale shop. Christopher intends to use the loan to buy sugar and soap to sell.

loans.use: to buy sugar and soap to sell.

loans.name: El Hadji

texts.fr: Monsieur   El  Hadji    est   un  homme marié habitant dans une des localités sénégalaises. Il s’active depuis 12 ans dans le secteur de la couture. Il est spécialisé  dans la confection et la vente d’habits prêts à porter. Grâce aux revenus que lui procure son activité il arrive a supporter les charges de location et de transport pour sa famille. Il est membre  d’un des guichets de l’UIMCEC  ou il est membre. Il sollicite un crédit de 50 000 frs prévu pour l’achat de tissus qui seront confectionnés et exposés a la vente. Avec  ce financement il pourra améliorer le niveau de ses  bénéfices, accroitre son épargne et aspirer dans le futur a l’acquisition d’un terrain.
texts.en:
Mr. El Hadji is a married man who lives in a commune in Senegal. For twelve years he's been in the tailoring business. He specializes in making and selling ready-to-wear clothing.

Thanks to the income generated by his business he manages to cover his family's housing and transport expenses.

He's a member of UIMCEC's local branch and is seeking a loan of XOF 50'000 intended to buy fabrics to be tailored and displayed for sale.

With this loan, he will be able to increase his profits and bolster his savings. In the future, he aspires to buy a land lot.

loans.use: to buy fabrics to tailor and sell

loans.name: Jappale Sor Dga 2 Group

texts.fr: Ndèye Bineta est une femme battante, mariée et mère de 5 enfants dont 3 belles jeunes filles et deux garçons. L’ainé a 26 ans et le tout dernier, 5 ans qui va à la garderie d’enfants du quartier. Elle a 45 ans et parait plus jeune que son âge. Elle est la présidente du Groupement Jappale Sor Daga 2. Son activité consiste à vendre des denrées alimentaires chez elle ou elle à ouvert une cantine depuis 10 ans maintenant. Avec le crédit elle veut renouveler son stock de marchandises. Ndèye Bineta commence sa journée de 8h – 13h le matin et le soir de 15h à 18h.  Elle va surtout acheter des effets de toilettes, des fruits, du poissons et des légumes  qui sont les denrées les plus utilisées et les plus rapides  à écouler. Elle compte sa clientèle  parmi son entourage qui aime bien cette vente à proximité très pratique. Elle n’a pas de charges imposées sinon que ce qu’elle a envie de faire concernant son foyer. Et cela fait qu’elle a toujours besoin de diversifier les produits et services pour son commerce dans l’avenir.
texts.en:
Ndèye Bineta is a real fighter. She's married and the mother of five children: three beautiful girls and two boys. The eldest is 26 years old, and the youngest is 5 and goes to the neighborhood's nursery.

Ndèye Bineta is 45 years old but looks younger. She's the president of Jappale Sor Daga 2 Group. Her business consists in selling food products at her home, where she opened a "cantine" (small shop) ten years ago. Her shop is open from 8 am to 1 pm in the morning, and from 3 to 6 pm in the afternoon.

With her loan, she wants to renew her stock. She will mainly buy toiletries, fruits, fish, and vegetables, which are the most used and fastest moving products. 

Her clientele comprises people from the neighborhood, who appreciate this local store and find it very practical. She doesn't have fixed expenses to cover except what she wants for her household.

For this reason, she always needs to diversify her product and service offering of her business for the future.

loans.use: to buy toiletries, fruits, fish, and vegetables

loans.name: Asliah

texts.en:
This is Asliah. She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to buy different products like shades, watches, and others to expand her product inventory. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

Asliah would like to apply for another 10,000 PHP loan for her to buy additional stocks of different products like shades, watches, etc, to expand her product inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profits. Asliah's profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Asliah hopes to be more successful in her business and dreams that her family will always stick together. Every week she meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for different products like shades, watches, and others to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Geraldine works hard to support her family.

She has a buy and sell vegetable business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from dried fish vending and selling frozen products. Geraldine is borrowing PHP 18000 through NWTF to buy additional stocks of vegetables to sell for her buy and sell vegetable business.

Geraldine has been sustaining her business activities through her past 5 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of vegetables to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
As a married parent of nine children, Mary works hard to support her family.

She has a restaurant business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending. Mary is borrowing PHP 10000 through NWTF to buy additional ingredients for her restaurant business.

Mary has been sustaining her business activities through her past 3 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients for her business

loans.name: Nonita

texts.en:
Nonita is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a making and selling dried fish business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 13000 through NWTF to purchase more fish for her making and selling dried fish business.

Nonita has been in this business for 26 years. She also earns more income from fishing.

Nonita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for her business

loans.name: Jeniffer

texts.en:
Jeniffer operates a beauty salon business, operating at the market where passersby and town dwellers go. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the loan she is requesting, Jeniffer wants to pay school fees and with the rest add stock into her beauty salon business. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future and she appreciates the support.

loans.use: to pay school fees and with the rest add stock into her beauty salon business.

loans.name: Pierre Yves

texts.fr: Pierre est un jeune camerounais de 25 ans. Célibataire sans enfants, il possède une alimentation depuis près de 02 ans dans un quartier de la ville . Ne disposant pas d'un stock assez consistant, Pierre souhaite avec l'argent du crédit, acheter les huiles de cuisine, la tomate, les sardines bref les produits de premières nécessité en grande quantité afin de satisfaire sa clientèle sans cesse grandissante. les bénéfices obtenus seront réinjectés dans l'activité et permettront également à Pierre de fonder sa famille.
texts.en:
Peter is a young 25-year-old Cameroonian. Single without children, he has owned a general food store for nearly two years in one of the city's districts.

As he does not have sufficient stock, Pierre wants to use the loan to buy cooking oil, tomatoes, sardines, in fact basic products in large quantities, to  meet the needs of an ever-growing clientele.

Profits will be reinvested in the business and also should allow Peter to start a family.

loans.use: buy merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy yams and fresh produce wholesale

loans.name: Benkadi I Group

texts.fr:
Les  10 membres du groupe  BENKADI I  sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à KOFLANI, un des villages de BAGUINEDA, 2ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur sixième  prêt avec l’institution.
La spéculation cultivée est  l’arachide avec  TENE, 1 ère debout de la gauche vers la droite  sur la photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, des semences et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  1,5 hectare. 
La production est vendue au niveau du village, à TIELE, après la récolte à une clientèle composée de revendeurs et de consommateurs. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice  de 190.000FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The 10 members of the BENKADI I group are married women who on average are 40 years old with four children. They all live in polygamous families in KOFLANI, one of the villages of BAGUINEDA, the second administrative region of Mali.

They work with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution to carry out their agricultural activities during the rainy season. They are on their sixth loan with the institution.

The featured member is Tene who cultivates groundnuts. She is the first person standing from left to right in the photo. She intends to use her loan to buy inputs, seeds and pay tillage costs for the maintenance of 1.5 hectares (3.7 acres). After harvesting, the crop is sold in Tiele to a client base of resellers and consumers.

She expects to make profits of 190,000 FCFA per growing season. Profits will allow her to pay off her loan and also help her husband with daily expenses.

loans.use: Pay for tillage, agricultural inputs and seeds

loans.name: Benkadi  Ii Group

texts.fr:
Les  10 membres du groupe  BENKADI II  sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans, 6 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à KOFLANI, un des villages de BAGUINEDA, 2ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur  sixième  prêt avec l’institution, remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est l’arachide  avec BINTOU , 1 ère debout de la droite vers la gauche  sur la photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, des semences et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir 1 hectare. 
La production est vendue au niveau du village, à  TIELE, après la récolte à une clientèle composée de revendeurs et de consommateurs. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 150.000FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Benkadi II group are married women who average 42 years of age with six children each; the majority of them live in polygamous families in Koflani, one of the villages in Baguineda, Mali's second administrative region.

They are collaborating with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso with the aim of carrying out their farming activities successfully during the winter season. They are on their sixth loan with the institution. 

Bintou, who is standing on the far right of the photo, grows groundnut. With her loan she is planning to buy fertilizers and seeds as well as to pay for labor to maintain around one hectare of land. Once harvested, the produce is sold in the village, in Tiele, to a customer bases made up of retailers and consumers. She is expecting to make a profit of 150,000FCFA per season. This profit will enable her to repay her loan and also help her husband out with the daily expenses.

loans.use: to pay for labor, the purchase of fertilizers and seeds.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
This is Marcelina.  She previously accessed an 32,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business.  Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better.  More items to sell will result in more profits.  Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and children’s education expenses.  She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Marcelina dreams that her business will continue to expand and hopes to have a good future.  She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Ivy

texts.en:
Ivy earns a living through her hog raising business.  She lives in Panglao, Bohol and has been in the business for more than 2 years now.  This is the main source of her income.

Ivy is asking for a loan to buy additional piglets to raise and more feed.  With this, she will be able to improve her business as well as her income.

loans.use: to buy additional pigletd to raise and more feed

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
This is Josefina. She previously accessed a 37,000 PHP loan, which she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 40,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profits. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Josefina dreams of being more successful in business and in life. She meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa works hard to support her family. Marissa is married and has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines.

Marissa has requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

Marissa has been in this business for three years now.

In the future, Marissa would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

loans.name: Marivel

texts.en:
Marivel is 40 years old and married with four children, three of whom are in school. Marivel works very hard to provide for her family.

Marivel runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell such as canned goods, milk, soap, noodles, eggs, etc.

Marivel has been in this business for 17 years.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her general store business.

In the future, Marivel would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell such as canned goods, milk, soap, noodles, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma works hard to support her family.  Vilma is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Vilma requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase an additional fishing boat and fishing materials for her business.  Vilma has been in this business for 27 years now.  In the future, Vilma would like to save enough to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase an additional fishing boat and fishing materials for her business

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita works hard to support her family.  Teresita is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.  Teresita requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stocks like soap, milk, can goods, etc to sell.

Teresita has been in this business for 10 years now.  She successfully paid back her previous loan and now is requesting a new loan to further build her general store business.  In the future, Teresita would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks like soap, milk, can goods, etc to sell

loans.name: Zhasmen

texts.en:
Zhasmen lives in Yerevan with her two daughters.  The elder one is married and she lives separately with her family.  Zhasmen is a widow and she with her second daughter have to work very hard in order to earn their living.  Zhasmen used to work as a teacher at the school, but since her husband has passed away she became seriously worried about her daughters living conditions and future, so she established her own business right in her house; in a very short period of time she became a skilled and good dressmaker. 

She mainly works on private order; she makes both men and women clothes (trousers, shirts, dresses).  Zhasmen’s daughter also helps her if there are a lot of orders so she does not have to manage it alone.  Recently she has taken a large order of uniform and bedclothes sewing.  She will send the prepared products to the Russian Federation.  The order is a very large one but the income also will be decent and Zhasmen with her daughter are very interested in making the order on time and properly. 

Zhasmen has already taken one loan from Nor Horizon and it is her first deal with Kiva lenders and she says that she is sure that it will be a continuous cooperation with great profit both for her and for Kiva lenders as well.  She asks for a loan in order to buy a lot of raw material for her sewing business, especially for the last order of uniforms and bedclothes.

loans.use: To buy a lot of rsw material for her sewing business in order to manage her orders of uniforms and bedclothes

loans.name: Jehova Es Mi Pastor Group

texts.es:
Jehová es mi pastor, está conformado por 13 miembros 11 mujeres y dos varones, madres y responsables con  25 hijos bajo su responsabilidad.  Son originarias de Malpaisillo, lugar que está ubicado en la zona norte del país. Estas personas se caracterizan por ser responsables, trabajadoras, con ganas de superación personal, los cuales luchan día  a día para proporcionarles el pan de cada a sus hijos, y  brindarles un futuro mejor. Ya que ellos por falta de recursos económicos no pudieron estudiar, y se vieron obligados  a  trabajar desde temprana edad.
Audelis es la coordinadora del banco comunal, y tiene por actividad económica una pulpería en su casa de habitación, una pulpería es una pequeña tienda que vende productos comestibles en cantidades pequeñas como sobre de café, sobre de shampoo, arroz, frijoles, azúcar, pan, leche, detergente, jabón, jugos, gaseosas, refrescos naturales, caja de fósforos. El objetivo del crédito es invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio en la compra y venta de productos comestibles, para que en un futuro no muy lejano pueda obtener mejores ingresos. El banco comunal Jehová es mi pastor agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva le brindan a  personas de escasos recursos y  países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
Jehová es mi Pastor is made up of 13 members, 11 women and two men. They are mothers and together are raising 25 people. They are from Malpaisillo, a place located in the northern part of the country. These people are characterized as responsible, hardworking, eager to get ahead personally. They fight day to day to bring home the daily bread to each of their children, and offer them a better future. Due to a lack of resources, they were unable to go to school and had to work at an early age. 

Audelis is the coordinator of the communal bank and her economic activity is a small pulperia in her house. A pulperia is a small store that sells edible products in small quantities such as coffee, shampoo, rice, beans, sugar, bread, milk, detergent, soap, juices, soft drinks, natural juices, and matches. The purpose of the loan is to invest in working capital and stock her business by buying and selling edible products so that in the not so distant future, she can obtain better income. The Jehová es mi Pastor communal bank is grateful for the help that the Kiva investors are giving to people of low income and poor countries such as Nicaragua, so that they may have dignified work.

loans.use: to invest in working capital and stock her store by buying products such as coffee, shampoo, beans, sugar, bread, milk, detergent, soap, juices, soft drinks, natural juices, and matches.

loans.name: Banco Comunal Amor De Mujeres Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Amor de Mujeres, está conformado por 15 integrantes, madre solteras responsables, de 35 hijos bajo su responsabilidad. Son ordinarias  del Sauce lugar que está ubicado en la zona de norte del país. El Sauce es un lugar que se caracteriza  por la producción de leche y quesos cuajadas. Son personas trabajadoras, responsables, con ganas de superación personal. Estas mujeres luchan día a día para sacar adelante a sus pequeños hijos y brindarles un futuro mejor, ya que ellas no pudieron estudiar por falta de recursos económicos, se vieron obligadas a trabajar desde temprana edad.
J
eylin Josefa es la coordinadora del banco comunal y  tiene por actividad económica la venta de ropa nueva variada como pantalones, camisas, faldas, short, vestidos, calcetas, camisolas, camisetas, ropa interior, sabanas toallas. El objetivo del crédito es invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio en la compra y venta de ropa variada, para que en un futuro no muy lejano pueda obtener mejores ingresos. Ella dedica a su negocio unas 10 horas diarias ofreciendo su mercadería, de forma ambulante con un bulto de unos 20 kg. El banco comunal Amor de Mujeres agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva les brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
The Amor de Mujeres communal bank is made up of 15 members, responsible single mothers with a total of 35 children under their care. They are from El Sauce, a place located in the northern part of the country. El Sauce is a place characterized by milk production and cheese curds. They are hardworking, responsible people who are eager to get ahead. These women fight day to day to get their little children ahead and offer them a better future, since they themselves couldn't go to school due to a lack of resources and had to start working at a young age. 


Jeylin Josefa is the coordinator of the communal bank and her economic activity is selling various items of new clothing such as pants, shirts, dresses, socks, camisoles, t-shirts, underwear, sheets and towels. The purpose of the loan is to invest in working capital and stock her business buying and selling new clothing so that in future she can make more income. She works at her business for about 10 hours a day, offering her merchandise as a street vendor with a 20 kg pack. The Amor de Mujeres communal bank is grateful for the help from the Kiva investors offer people of low income in poor countries such as Nicaragua so that they can have dignified work.

loans.use: to invest in working capital and stock her business of buying and selling merchandise such as pants, shirts, skirts, shorts, dresses, socks, camisoles, t-shirts, underwear, sheets and towels.

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
Rosie is 31 years old and married with two children. With two children currently in school, Rosie works very hard to provide for them.

Rosie runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional inventory for her general store.

Rosie has been in this business for 5 years and sells a variety of items such as shampoo, snack foods, canned goods, soft-drinks, and cooking oil.
